Subjective: Right eye irritation, onset Tuesday AM. Woke with sensation of foreign body (dust/hair). Rubbed eye. Increased redness, visible red veins. Right eye thicker than left. Researched online, suspects eye infection. Feels like constant foreign body. Squeezing eyes shut causes pain. No visual changes, no photophobia. No other eye symptoms previously. No new cosmetics. No trauma. No recent illness (flu). Daughter (Isa) healthy. Boyfriend on holiday. Managing alone with daughter. Concerned about contagion and worsening symptoms. Request: Wants to know if eye drops or antibiotics needed.
Objective: Right eye: Redness, visible dilated conjunctival vessels. Left eye: Mild redness noted. Pupils: Reactive to light bilaterally. No foreign body seen on external exam or under eyelids. No discharge noted.
Assessment: Viral conjunctivitis, bilateral. Right eye initially more affected, now left eye showing signs. No evidence of bacterial superinfection or foreign body.
Plan:
1. Reassurance: Viral conjunctivitis, self-limiting.
2. Hygiene: Avoid rubbing eyes.
3. Symptomatic relief: Artificial tears PRN for comfort (Kruidvat available).
4. Lid hygiene: Lukewarm tap water with cotton pad for morning crusting.
5. Safety netting: Return if increased pain, increased pus/discharge, or vision changes.
6. Follow-up: Return in 2 weeks if symptoms persist.
